title: Between 17 March 2017 and 30 April 2017, will a U.S. Cabinet-level nomination fail or will a Cabinet-level member of the administration cease to hold their office?
preds: Affirming forecast for the passage of time.

A nomination failing to be passed by the US Senate is extremely rare, as most tend to withdraw their names rather than be outright denied.  The last time a nominee was outright rejected was under George H. W. Bush in 1989.  Additionally, Trump cabinet members follow the president in their tendency to be overly stubborn, so I sincerely doubt any of them will willingly leave office.
3 days left and no word of anything
Only 8 days left for this forecast to happen.
No indication that the three remaining vacancies will be withdrawn or fail in any way
Realizing I was overestimating the odds that Priebus is forced out. So dropping thirty points to 15.
Comments: Situation on the Korean Peninsula dominating this news cycle. Incremental adjustment down.
Trump and his cabinet are pretty much out of the woods.  No one is probably leaving at this point.
Dem-GOP draws the majority of its leadership from the same pool: over 55, white, lawyer or business man. Trump is their man now.

Congress is in recess until 5 days before this question closes, so a failure looks unlikely. I'm asking myself why anyone would get sacked.  It seems to me that sackings occur because of some real or perceived mistake.  With Congress in recess and no legislation pending for immediately after it's back in session, there's not like to be a legislative failure.  The other reason a person might be sacked was for something uncovered in an investigation. . . .like a Russian connection?  But, again, with Congress in recess and all investigations stalled, I don't think that's likely; investigations are never speedy. What about political infighting?  I've read a lot about conflict between Bannon  & Priebus, but that seems to be smoothing out and Bannon seems to have lost some of his influence.  See aaseawaf15 http://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/480639

The Hill (opinion), April 8, 'Report: Priebus's job safe but Bannon in danger': http://thehill.com/homenews/administration/327945-report-priebuss-job-safe-but-bannon-in-danger
Clips from Hill article:
"White House Chief of Staff Reince Priebus's job is safe despite reports of a potential staff shake-up, Axios reported Saturday.
The official told Axios that Priebus is "with the program" of a more cooperative and inclusive approach for the White House.
But the report said chief White House strategist Stephen Bannon is increasingly isolated and will be forced out if he is unable to adopt a cooperative approach.
 Several outlets have reported that Bannon is frequently clashing with Trump's adviser and son-in-law Jared Kushner as well as the president's daughter Ivanka Trump.
Both Ivanka Trump and Kushner reportedly want a more moderate and results-oriented approach for the White House, while Bannon refuses to find common ground."
Comments: I have to agree with this.  NYT, April 7, 'For 2 Advisers, Syria Strike Is a Chance to Step Out of the Shadows': https://www.nytimes.com/2017/04/07/world/middleeast/tillerson-mcmaster-syria-attack.html?_r=0
Clips from NYT article:
"Major foreign-policy upheavals can be a crucible, propelling some administration figures to the forefront while others fade. But the Trump administration has faced a more basic challenge: persuading the world, after weeks of bureaucratic dysfunction, that it can handle fast-moving events.
For an administration that has lurched from crisis to crisis, often seeming to make things up as it goes along, this was a chance for Mr. Tillerson and Mr. McMaster to offer a forceful explanation of Mr. Trump’s thinking. For both men, who have struggled with personnel upheavals at their agencies and doubts about their place in Mr. Trump’s turbulent orbit, it was a chance to show that they were wielding influence over critical national security decisions." 
Comments: The gas attack in Syria and following global outrage came at the right time. Good for Mattis. Incremental adjustment down.
Curtailing Bannon good for longevity of cabinet republicans, including reince prebius.
Rumors that Priebus might be leaving. Have to keep an eye on it.
There are enough rumors that Priebus is on the way out that I'm starting to think there will be a shakeup sometime this month.

Presumably a "Cabinet-level" official is one for whom Senate confirmation is required, as opposed to just someone from the awkward squad on the White House staff, who are appointed by and serve at the pleasure of.  So far the remaining Cabinet-level folks under this .definition are safe, since it will take longer than this deadline to spot the leakers and sack them.  If you don't care much how the country turns out, the next several years should be great fun.

The timing for this question is way too short. 
They all will hold their horses for now, then it depends on what is happening. Some cabinets are more difficult than others to hold. 
I can see the Ambassador to the United Nations; Nikki Haley holding pretty well, while a more unsteady seats is the Attorney General Jeff Sessions'; but for him and many others it depends on how the various scandals will surface/develop. 
Secretary of the Treasury, Steven Mnuchin doesn't have a though job as Timothy F. Geithner did. While Paul O'Neil was fired in December 2002 after a year on the job by a [on hindsight] a less tumultous administration than the present one. Mnuchin will hold on for a while. To me the one that has the toughest job is Rex Tillerson. To my surprise Tillerson CV is rather thin (see below); Eagle Scout, bus boy, and janitor are not working experiences that will help him much in diplomacy. Neither is CEO since Diplomacy is the art and practice of conducting negotiations between representatives of states. it is the conduct of international relations to issues of peace-making, trade, war, economics, culture, environment, and human rights. 
Tillerson is clearly non-qualified (as others are in Trump's cabinet), the job of Secretary of State is particularly demanding and stressful. If then the White House continues the 'know-nothing approach' to foreign policy, I can actually see Tillerson resigning. Active in the Boy Scouts of America for most of his life, he earned the rank of Eagle Scout in 1965. At 14 he began to work as a bus boy in the student union building at Oklahoma State University. Two years later in 1968 he became a janitor working in one of the engineering buildings at the University.  Tillerson graduated from Huntsville High School in 1970. He received a bachelor's degree in civil engineering from the University of Texas at Austin in 1975. During his time at UT Austin, he was involved with the Tejas Club, the Longhorn Band, and Alpha Phi Omega. In 2006 he was named a Distinguished Engineering Graduate.
Perdue and Lighthizer are not yet confirmed.  No current cabinet member is drawing significant, active and prolonged negative attention.

No scheduled confirmation hearings for remaining Cabinet positions. Bannon removed from NSC eases some of the tension between WH and SecDef, SecHS, and NSA. There are still 25 days to go, but unless the administration really goes off the rails or a major scandal breaks on one of the members already in place, it's unlikely to happen.
Adjusting down for the passage of time.

Seems like the remaining 3 aren't in any danger of failing, so that leaves resignation.. sessions/russia ties seem like the most plausible situation that would result in a vacancy, maybe outside chance of Pruitt having internal issues with the EPA also.  But seems like nothing imminent this month..

I think this year we will see a cabinet member resign because so many are unsuited for the job. But I think all of them can hold out another month. As for nominees failing to get the votes, I think the majority party is going to make sure they do.
Too early for the rats to abandon ship. And too short a timeframe for them to be kicked out.

...or a cabinet level member of the administration cease to hold their office. "You're fired!" This is a pretty easy one. Another Michael Flynn is just around the corner. I would put Rick Perry or Rex Tillerson (or maybe now Tom Price) close to the top of the list. I had a megalomaniacal boss who would hire individuals with high credentials only to fire them. The firing of well-respected people was the reason to hire them. Trump seems like the type to do that, and I expect the likelihood to increase now that repeal and replace failed.
As more and more information about Russian intervention is revealed, I believe certain cabinet members will be forced to resign.
Based on general news and GJP consensus.
The waters are murky, but the timeline is short.
If Preibus is a part of the cabinet then it is plausible that he could be scapegoated for any legislative failures.
At least one of the opportunists who initially clamored for a  ride on the "Trump Train" will conclude that it's too career damaging to continue with a failing administration.

"You cannot allow any of your people to avoid the brutal facts. If they start living in a dream world, it’s going to be bad." - Gen. James Mattis, USMC (ret). Politico, March 22, 'Hill Republicans say they're growing frustrated with Mattis - The Marine general was welcomed as a moderating force in the Trump administration, but his moves to name Obama veterans to Pentagon posts are irritating allies in key committees': http://www.politico.com/story/2017/03/mattis-defense-hill-republicans-obama-236329
Clips from article:
“That’s it,” Trump said, slapping his palm down on the wooden table, according to those sources. “Patterson’s out.” Moments later, an administration official placed a call to Mattis to inform him that he needed another nominee for the position.
Defense Department veterans say the White House has put Mattis in a nearly impossible position given that a large swath of the Republican foreign-policy establishment was openly critical of Trump during the campaign. Some say that has left Mattis with little choice but to turn to Democrats and to those without a political background to fill senior posts.
“In picking Mattis, the president got someone who had bipartisan credibility and was seen as a tough national security official who wasn’t going to toe the White House or the GOP line,” said Jeremy Bash, a former Pentagon spokesman under Secretary Leon Panetta. “Independence is an important attribute in a SecDef. But when you get that, you get frustration from the political folks. When you’re not coming out of the establishment, you have the credibility to do bipartisan things. You’re just going to take incoming from Democrats and from Republicans from time to time.” "Others said it’s crucial that Mattis embrace the reality of navigating the Hill. “Everybody thinks very highly of him, but he doesn’t have any political sense, and he doesn’t think he needs any political sense,” said one former Bush administration Defense Department official. “But it’s quintessentially a political job.” Comments: See intelligence fiasco continuing (reveals Nunes as a Trump brown-noser), while vulnerable Sessions probably scrambling to cover tracks. Expect Mattis reaching frustration-point-of-no-return and not wanting to associate himself further with a dysfunctional administration/Congress. Most likely head back to semi-retirement in Seattle and watch DC carnage from afar.  Strongly believe this will occur post-100 days. Incremental adjustment down.
Dems will get momentum with AHCA failure.

Trump loses Ryan wins, calls Trump ineffective and get the conservative base to back Ryan. Ryan tells the conservative base Trump should be impeached over the Russian connection changing the focus on healthcare to Trump corruption and we spent the best part of the rest of the year impeaching Trump so Ryan can clam we need to get rid of Trump to get rid of ObamaCare.  Rex Tillerson will resign soon, probably while Trump is being Impeached. Then Ryan will try to cut Obama Care
With Perdue stalled, questions about Acosta's past, and a Cabinet that was rubber stamped into office, high potential for something to go awry even in such a limited timeframe.

With the majority and ability to push through any of Trump's nominations regardless of Democratic party opposition, it seems very unlikely that any nominations fail to be confirmed. There seems to be no new negative stories on most of Trump's current cabinet members so it seems unlikely that any step down as well.
Problem picks are already through (DeVos) or have withdrawn (Pudzer). Unlikely that anyone else had Flynn-level misdemeanors, so unlikely anyone else will step down.

Cutting deals with pedophiles not going to help get votes.   He might have to withdraw that is why I am upping mine to 60%. http://www.marketwatch.com/story/trumps-ex-campaign-chairman-manafort-worked-to-advance-putins-interests-labor-nominee-acosta-cut-deal-with-billionaire-2017-03-22
too early for a problem of this magnitude

I think the worst is behind us in terms of cabinet position approval controversy.  There is a very small chance of a resignation in this short time frame, but the only trigger I can think of for now is an uncomfortable Russian connection.  The FBI testified about some murky connections, but nothing solid yet.  I would expect them to proceed carefully in they wanted to make specific accusations, and that takes longer than a fat month.

Resignations most likely, as noted by others. Very limited time-frame, but Trump has some very strong personality issues. I suspect a motivator for the question given the timeframe is whether evidence of witting collusion or corruption will be uncovered in the next 40 days.
Someone might resign. Will lower with passage of time.

Tillerson is the only one that openly has said that he does not like the job.  But from there to walk away is a long path, he is not a quitter, he will stick around at least for the ruffles to decrease and then walk away but for that you are looking at a couple of years.
There are a couple of ways to measure this one, the first is withdrawal from the nomination like the labor position. Now, will the senate fail to nominate a candidate? That is a different situation and today with the "loss" for the-deal-maker with the ACA. I am sure that there is going to be lots of push to get muscle specially with nominations.....wins need to be manufactured!
I'm putting this at 50/50 as Comey's investigation could lead to another situation like Flynn - although the odds of that happening before 30 April isn't certain.
50/50 shot, In My Humble Opinion. There are a lot of really stupid things going on in this administration, and someone's got to call their bluff eventually.

Remaining nominees are not overly controversial. USG doesn't move fast enough to remove a Cabinet member prior to the deadline. No incentive to resign beyond sending a message. Mattis would be the most likely candidate to resign, based on the increasingly adversarial relationship between WH and Pentagon.

I don't believe this is likely, clearly, and I don't think any of the remaining nominees will withdraw, but I think there is a chance someone else will resign. Given the range of scandals the administration is dealing with, and the generally dysfunctional setup, I can see people very quickly getting frustrated and leaving (looking at Mattis and Tillerson here).
Republicans with ensure approval, not enough time for forced resignation

I'm going with 1 percent because there's always a chance something happens, but Acosta and Lighthizer seem like safe picks. That only leaves Perdue. While he has some baggage, he also has the necessary support.  It also seems unlikely anybody will leave before April 30, although Mattis might have a resignation letter that only needs to be dated and signed following the Anne Patterson debacle.
Price is the only one that may be a casualty, but with SDNY AG fired it's unlikely that there will be any meaningful investigation on what appears to be possible insider trading by the new Secretary

None of the 4 remaining cabinet nominees - Sonny Purdue, Robert Lighthizer, Alexander Acosta and Daniel Coats - are particularly controversial. I don't see any major obstacles to their confirmation. The real question is if any of the current cabinet officials step down. I believe the 2 most likely to step down would be Jeff Sessions and Tom Price. At a minimum, Sessions may have committed perjury concerning the Russia question. Tom Price, on the other hand, may have committed insider trading. Former Fed Atty Preety Bharara was apparently investigating him at the time of his firing. Though even if one of the 2 were to step down, I find it unlikely that it would occur in 41 days.

Failure methods Failed nominations include nominations that are withdrawn, returned to the President by the Senate, and those which are voted down by the Senate 2 of those 3 methods of failure involve the senate, yet there has been a 100% success rate with all nominees being confirmed by the senate.  Since taking office, 19 of President Trump's cabinet nominees have been confirmed by the Senate, one nomination has been withdrawn, and three remain vacant  95% success rate, 5% failure rate. Multiplied by 1/3rd = 1.666%.

Acosta and Purdue look like good bets to get confirmed. With the lax vetting that has been part of the Trump administration it is always possible that there is a skeleton in the closet but I put the odds low. One dark horse for a cabinet member to resign would be Priebus, he would make a good scapegoat for any problems that may come up in the next few weeks.
I can no longer trust what seems even vaguely rational when it comes 2 this syphallitic idiot
Low likelihood on remaining open positions; someone in office might leave for unforeseen reasons.

Mattis...... going low due to time constraints.
Washington Post, March 14, 'Defense Secretary Mattis withdraws Patterson as choice for undersecretary for policy': https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/national-security/defense-secretary-mattis-withdraws-patterson-as-choice-for-undersecretary-for-policy/2017/03/14/dd5ec8bc-08b6-11e7-93dc-00f9bdd74ed1_story.html?utm_term=.92472e81424e
Clips from article:
"Mattis’s acquiescence to Patterson’s withdrawal came after he fought and won a major battle with the White House to remove Iraq from the list of majority-Muslim countries whose citizens are barred from U.S. entry under Trump’s executive order on immigration.
Although he reportedly insisted that he be able to select his own team when he accepted Trump’s offer to head the Defense Department, Mattis has skirmished repeatedly with the White House over appointments. His initial choice for deputy secretary, Michèle Flournoy, withdrew from consideration after meetings with White House officials. Flournoy served as the department’s undersecretary in the Obama administration."
